G.L. c. 186..proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant has been Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord shall not “directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant,” and a landlord who does so is liable for actual and statutory damages, costs, and reasonable attorney’s fees.

G.L. c. 223.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223 and the applicable District Court venue rules because the leased premises are located in Somerville, Massachusetts, and the acts and omissions complained of occurred in this Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: Massachusetts law further recognizes that a landlord’s pattern of ignoring tenant complaints and failing to correct conditions can warrant multiple damages and fee shifting under various housing statutes designed to protect tenants’ basic living conditions.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: In Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977), the Supreme Judicial Court held that a landlord may be liable for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment where the landlord’s failure to control activities on adjacent property he also controls (such as a noisy lounge) results in substantial interference with tenants’ use of their apartments, even if the landlord did not personally create the noise.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that the landlords breached the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment where substantial noise from a lounge on adjacent premises they also controlled constructively evicted the tenants, despite the landlords not intending or personally creating the noise. The court emphasizes that liability arises where the disturbing condition is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord permitted and where the landlord had the right and ability to control the objectionable activity. This directly matches the proposition stated.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: "Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable. Tenants such as these should not be left only with a claim against the proprietors of the noisome lounge.... we decline to perpetuate that distinction where the landlord creates a situation and has the right to control the objectionable conditions."

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: A landlord’s persistent failure to respond reasonably to tenant complaints about serious and ongoing interference can constitute “direct or indirect” interference under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court squarely interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14’s phrase “directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment” and holds that malicious intent is not required, and that at least reckless conduct, including omissions, can create liability. It then applies that standard to Gem’s persistent failure to remedy repeated, serious flooding despite tenant complaints, and concludes that this conduct constituted interference with quiet enjoyment under § 14. That directly supports the proposition that a landlord’s persistent failure to respond reasonably to serious ongoing interference can amount to “direct or indirect” interference under the statute.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “When § 14 was first enacted… In 1973, the statute was rewritten… landlords were now liable for ‘directly or indirectly’ interfering with tenants’ quiet enjoyment of leased premises. One natural inference from this amendment is that the Legislature meant to abrogate the requirement of specific intent… In sum… Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: A landlord’s persistent failure to respond reasonably to tenant complaints about serious and ongoing interference can constitute “direct or indirect” interference under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses whether a landlord’s inaction in the face of serious, ongoing third‑party misconduct can be a “direct or indirect” interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court holds that if the landlord effectively “stood idle” despite tenant complaints and available measures to remove wrongdoers, that inaction can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment, to be resolved as a factual question on remand. This directly supports the proposition that persistent failure to respond reasonably to serious interference can amount to “direct or indirect” interference under the statute.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We do believe, however, that if the defendant has failed to take any measures, especially those measures which can be undertaken relatively easily, to remove unwelcome persons from the property that it owns and controls, and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.… If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771, 776–78 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.proposition: Defendant’s inaction and refusal to meaningfully intervene, in the face of known and ongoing interference, constitute “indirect interference” with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability and, in passing, notes that the trial judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but it does not analyze what constitutes a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14, nor does it address the concept of ‘indirect interference’ or a landlord’s inaction in the face of third‑party interference. The court’s focus is entirely on the proper measure of damages for habitability breaches in subsidized housing. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition that a defendant’s inaction and refusal to intervene constitutes indirect interference within the meaning of § 14.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.relevant_excerpt: “Although the judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, he awarded no damages on this claim to avoid what would have been a duplicative award. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 107-111 (1982).”

AlZiab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u2.proposition: The interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment caused by Defendant’s conduct and omissions was substantial, material, and not merely trifling or transitory.
AlZiab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss the degree of interference (substantial vs. trifling) with quiet enjoyment. Instead, it addresses whether a statutory lead paint violation, by itself and without proof of landlord fault, constitutes a violation of the quiet enjoyment statute, holding that at least negligent conduct with notice is required. There is no analysis or language about the interference being substantial, material, or non‑trifling, so the case does not support that specific proposition.
AlZiab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u2.relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Massachusetts law further recognizes that a landlord’s pattern of ignoring tenant complaints and failing to correct conditions can warrant multiple damages and fee shifting under various housing statutes designed to protect tenants’ basic living conditions.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses implied warranty of habitability, the interaction with the State Sanitary Code, and available statutory remedies (e.g., G.L. c. 239, § 8A; G.L. c. 111, §§ 127F, 127H, 127L), but it does not address multiple damages or fee shifting. There is no language indicating that a landlord’s pattern of ignoring complaints or failing to correct conditions gives rise to enhanced or punitive damages, nor any discussion of attorney’s fees. The case focuses on rent abatement and the interdependence of rent and repair obligations, not on statutory multiple damages or fee-shifting mechanisms.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “The Code is not solely penal in nature. By G. L. c. 111, § 127C, as amended by St. 1969, c. 242, and § 127H, as amended by St. 1972, c. 201, a tenant may file a petition in the District or Superior Court to enforce compliance with the Code by the landlord; and by § 127K, inserted by St. 1968, c. 404, § 2, any agreement by the tenant to waive that right is declared to be against public policy and void.”
